Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: All-Dielectric Optical Metasurfaces For Controlling Wave Fronts

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop metasurfaces for manipulating the phase and wavefront of light with near-unity efficiency for realizing ultra-compact optical elements such as lenses, waveplates, and beam formers. The approach is to use arrays of nanoscale dielectric resonators to form metasurfaces with low absorption loss. High efficiency will be achieved by overlapping electric and magnetic resonances, allowing full control over the amplitude and phase of the transmitted light. This freedom will be employed to realize optical elements as well as metasurfaces for controlling the polarization of light.
This research will result in a better fundamental understanding of how electric and magnetic resonances can be independently manipulated in single high index resonators, yielding new insights into metasurface and low-loss optical antenna design. The role of coupling between resonators will also be determined, allowing a more accurate representation of the desired phase profile and better device performance. Lastly, this research will result in a better understanding of how to manipulate and harness anisotropy in dielectric antennae.
This research will lead to a new class of ultra-compact optical elements which can improve the performance and integration of a wide range of devices such as visible and infrared cameras, polarimetric imagers, and spatial light modulators as well as be an enabling technology for applications such as free-space telecommunications and optical manipulation. The research will have a strong educational and outreach component focused on providing awareness, exposure, and excitement of science to students from all backgrounds and educational levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has resulted in the development of novel ultrahin optical components based on nanostructured metamaterials. There have been a number of pioneering scientific advancements in nonlinear media, ultrathin optical components, and reconfigurable optical elements.This award has also resulted in the training of the next generation of researchers including many students from underrepresented groups.

Non-linear media are commonly used as frequency converters but the challenge in using these materials is that the conversion efficiency is quite low. In this program we demonstrated how nanostructured metamaterials can be used to achieve a record, 10,000X, improvement in the frequency conversion efficiency. These types of materials could see use in the next generation of lasers, optical switches, and eye protection.

We also demonstrated how nanostructured metamaterials can be used to reduce the size and weight of current optical systems such as those found in imaging systems, sensors, and displays. In particular, we demonstrated how thin multi-wavelength lenses, much thinner than a human hair, can be realized. This technology was also extended to polarization optics as well as three-dimensional holograms. These technologies have wide ranging applications in reducing the size and/or increasing the functionality of imaging systems, next generation displays, augmented reality, or optical signal analysis devices.

Finally, the award resulted in the development of dynamically tunable optical components. These elements can be used to reconfigure and optical system on-demand and in real-time. These materials could be used for beam steering in laser ranging systems or as display devices for consumer electronics. 

In addition to the scientific advancements, this award resulted in the training of numerous graduate, undergraduate, high school, and middle school researchers including many from underrepresented groups. Students were trained in the principle investigator's lab as well as in outreach events designed to encourage students to consider careers in science and engineering fields. This includes tutorials on optics held at a nearby HBCU and attended by underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students. All of the high school and undergraduate students involved in the research have chosen to pursue bachelors or doctorate degrees, respectively, in engineering. This includes 3 female students, a group that is underrepresented in engineering fields. Three graduate students were supported and they have all received their PhDs.
